You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Background: An undirected graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a mathematical object made up of a set of objects called vertices, Vğ‘‰V, and a set of connections between them called edges, EâŠ†VÃ—Vğ¸ğ‘‰ğ‘‰E\subseteq V\times V.
The graph layout (embedding) problem involves assigning positions to the vertices, typically in the 2D Euclidean space, subject to predefined optimization goals, such as maintaining graph-theoretic distances or showing clustersÂ .
We restrict ourselves to two-dimensional, straight-line layouts, and refer to them as graph drawings. A large corpus of algorithms to produce such drawings exist; seeÂ  for a recent survey. stress metricÂ     , defined formally in SectionÂ 3. All vector norms ||..||||..|| that appear in this paper refer to the Euclidean 2-norm. Different graph drawing algorithms are designed to optimize different aesthetic criteriaÂ 4 3    and different evaluation metrics have been proposedÂ 8 1.
PurchaseÂ 8 proposed seven metrics for aesthetic criteria, including symmetry. It is not obvious how to compute a measure of symmetry, for example KlapaukhÂ 1 suggests an edge-based metric that explicitly calculates reflection, rotation and translation symmetries, whereas the metric defined by PurchaseÂ 8 considers only reflective symmetry, ignoring rotational symmetry. A later study shows that the values of these metrics respond erratically to the scale of the drawing while stress behaves predictablyÂ . In many settings it is desirable to evaluate a drawing based on how well the graph structure is captured in the layout. Such quality metricsÂ 8 capture how well a particular drawing represents the structure present in the abstract graph data.
The most popular family of metrics
of this type is stress.
Many variants of stress exist, and we describe several of them in SectionÂ 3.
A drawing with low stress implies that the Euclidean distance between any two vertices in the drawing is close to the corresponding graph-theoretic distance between them.
Human-subject experiments investigating the geometric properties of graph drawings show that people prefer graph drawings with lower stressÂ 2. The notion of stress originates from the field of statistical analysis, where it is used as a dimension reduction (DR) technique. The class of dimension reduction algorithms that directly optimize stress are known as Multi-Dimensional Scaling (MDS), of which there are dozens of variants; seeÂ  [ref]6 . Confusingly, there are three main classes of distance-based DR techniques known as MDS sometimes used interchangeably. We use the following definitions: Classical MDSÂ  was proposed by Torgerson and is the earliest method. It makes assumptions that the distances are obtained from a Euclidean vector space which allows a closed-form solution to be derived. Given the similarity matrix BğµB, the closed-form solution of Xğ‘‹X where X=Î›1/2â€‹Vâ€²ğ‘‹superscriptÎ›12superscriptğ‘‰â€²X=\Lambda^{1/2}V^{\prime} can be found from the eigenvalue decomposition of BğµB such that B=Vâ€‹Î›â€‹Vâ€²ğµğ‘‰Î›superscriptğ‘‰â€²B=V\Lambda V^{\prime}. While very consistent, the visual quality of Classical MDS for graph drawing is generally quite poor, but its closed form solution makes it a nice initialization for other drawing methodsÂ  2. Metric MDSÂ 9 was later proposed by Shepard as a generalization of Classical MDS. Here, EquationÂ 1 is modeled as a differentiable equation in the coordinates and gradient-based approaches can be applied to optimize it. This variant is the most widely used in graph drawing, starting with Kamada and KawaiÂ 0, followed by Gansner et al.Â 4 and Zheng et al.Â [ref]49. Non-Metric MDSÂ 4 is interested in both finding an embedding of the points in low dimensional space, and a non-parametric relationship between them. At each step of the algorithm, a monotonic curve of best fit must be found in the drawingâ€™s Shepard diagram, a plot with embedded distances on the x-axis and high dimensional distances on the y-axis. The smaller the horizontal distances between the curve and points of the diagram are, the better the quality of the embedding is.
Instead of exact distances, this variant only attempts to preserve the ranks between points. To the best of our knowledge, this variant has not yet been applied to graph layouts. Graph Drawing by Minimizing Stress: In 1989, Kamada and KawaiÂ 0 proposed an algorithm that attempts to match the Euclidean distances in the layout to the abstract graph-theoretic distances.
CohenÂ 3 built on Kamada and Kawaiâ€™s work by creating an incremental approach where successively larger portions of the graph are arranged based on KK stress.
Gansner et al.Â 4 adapted stress majorization, a technique already known in the MDS community, to improve the optimization process.
Stress computation can be expensive for large graphs since it relies on an all-pairs-shortest-path algorithmÂ  7. Hence Gansner et al.Â  adapted the stress definition to emphasize only adjacent vertices and introduced an entropy component.
Later, Gansner et al.Â  reformulated stress using the eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian to provide a scalable sparse representation. Optimizing stress has also been useful when optimizing other aesthetic criteria.
Huang et al.Â  show that the inclusion of multiple aesthetic criteria can lead to increased effectiveness and understanding of the resulting visualizations.
Devkota et al.Â  use stress optimization for better optimization of edge crossings and crossing angles in their Stress-Plus-X (SPX) algorithm. Wang et al.Â  reformulate the stress function to impose constraints on both the edge vectors and lengths, which enables them to model many layout constraints.
Simultaneous, multi-criteria optimization, has been generalized to a broader set of aesthetic criteria, including neighborhood preservation, ideal edge lengths, vertex resolution, angular resolution, and aspect ratio in (Gâ€‹D)2superscriptğºğ·2(GD)^{2} (Graph Drawing via Gradient Descent)Â . Zheng et al.Â [ref]49 showed that stochastic gradient descent is effective for stress optimization and
BÃ¶rsig et al. Â  confirm these results, showing that it produces high-quality results and is indifferent to initialization conditions.
Multicriteria Scalable Graph Drawing via Stochastic Gradient Descent, (Sâ€‹Gâ€‹D)2superscriptğ‘†ğºğ·2(SGD)^{2}, builds on these resultsÂ . Stress-based evaluations: Stress is widely used to measure the quality of a network layout.
Xue et al.Â  and Hong et al.Â  use normalized stress as an evaluation metric.
Stress is also used to evaluate dynamic graph layoutsÂ  .
Recently, Di Bartolomeo et al.Â  reviewed the graph drawing literature and provided a list of standard approaches to evaluate graph layout algorithms. According to their study of 100+ articles, stress is the third most frequently used evaluation metric after running time and number of crossings. Initially, raw stress was defined to measure the quality of the embeddingÂ [ref]6. It was observed that raw stress score varies if the layout is resizedÂ [ref]6. Normalized stressÂ   4 6 3 was proposed to address this issue, but as we will show, it also suffers from problems with a change in scale.
Several other variants of stress are also proposed including resizing multiple layouts to the same windowÂ 3, scaling the graph distances so that the layout distance is proportional to graph distanceÂ 0, etc. With this in mind, we describe several such variants in the following sections and show the impact of scale.
